Article Title: 'Genital or bodily mutilation': US House passes bill banning gender-affirming care for minors; heads to Senate

WASHINGTON: The US House of Representatives on Wednesday passed a Republican-backed bill seeking to ban gender-affirming care for minors, a move that would make several medical procedures a federal crime. The legislation was approved by a narrow 216-211 vote and now heads to the Senate, where its prospects remain uncertain.The bill, sponsored by Republican lawmaker Marjorie Taylor Greene, outlaws what it describes as ‚Äúgenital or bodily mutilation of a minor,‚Äù a provision that would effectively prohibit gender-affirming medical treatments for transgender children. While many US states have already enacted similar bans, the measure would establish a nationwide prohibition.‚ÄúThis important bill...will criminalize gender-affirming care on minors, not adults, on minors who have not yet grown up to make adult decisions,‚Äù Greene said ahead of the vote.The legislation explicitly criminalises female genital mutilation but also targets surgeries intended to alter a minor‚Äôs body ‚Äúto correspond to a sex that differs from their biological sex.‚Äù It further restricts certain pharmacological treatments, including the use of puberty blockers.Under the bill, anyone performing or facilitating such procedures could face up to 10 years in prison along with financial penalties.Greene described the measure as ‚Äúa direct reflection of President Trump's executive order and every single Republican's campaign promise in 2024.‚ÄùFormer president Donald Trump campaigned aggressively against transgender-related policies during last year‚Äôs election and moved early in his second term to roll back measures recognising diverse gender identities. His administration has also sought to bar transgender people from military service and reduce funding for schools that allow transgender athletes to compete in women‚Äôs sports.Democratic lawmaker Sarah McBride, the first openly transgender person elected to Congress, criticised the bill. ‚ÄúAll Republican politicians care about is making the rich richer and attacking trans people,‚Äù the Delaware representative told reporters outside the Capitol.Transgender rights group Advocates for Trans Equality said the legislation ‚Äúattempts to strip both transgender and intersex people of their freedom to make decisions about their own bodies.‚Äù The group noted that the bill continues to allow surgeries on intersex children, describing them as ‚Äúnon-consensual surgeries that are actual cases of mutilation.‚Äù‚ÄúThe bill is not about protecting children -- it is about enforcing outdated ideas of sex and gender through coercion and violence,‚Äù said A4TE health policy analyst Sinead Murano-Kinney.

Article Title: US travel ban hits top talent: Iranian biologist with more than 200 citations forced to abandon Harvard postdoc
Article Text:
Top talent caught in the US‚ÄìIran conflict





How the 2025 travel ban changed the rules

‚ÄòMuslims Sucking Our Resources‚Äô: Republican Andy Ogles Tells Trump To Deport All Muslim Immigrants

Rushing to outrun a policy shift

A forced pivot to Canada

Innovation versus immigration politics

Living with permanent uncertainty









For nearly a year, Delaram Pouyabahar planned her next academic step around a postdoctoral position at Harvard University. Interviews, fellowship applications, visa paperwork and a consular interview in Toronto were all completed. Then, in early June 2025, a new US travel ban quietly brought those plans to a halt.The policy, announced on June 4, expanded the scope of the 2017 travel ban to 19 countries, including Iran. Unlike the earlier ban, which still allowed many students and academic researchers to enter the US after delays or special approvals, the new rules removed those pathways altogether. According to Pouyabahar‚Äôs own public account, her visa process simply stalled after the ban took effect, leaving her unable to take up the Harvard postdoc she had spent months preparing for.Pouyabahar is not an obscure or early stage applicant. She is an Iranian born computational biologist specialising in machine learning methods for single cell RNA sequencing, a fast growing area at the intersection of AI and life sciences. One of her Nature journal papers has been cited more than 200 times, an unusually high figure for an early career researcher and a marker of broad influence within the field.Her work focuses on developing tools that help scientists interpret complex biological data, methods that are now used by research groups worldwide.In a global academic system that prizes measurable impact, citation counts and journal quality, her profile places her among the most competitive candidates for elite postdoctoral positions.The 2025 travel ban goes further than its 2017 predecessor. While the earlier policy eventually allowed exemptions for F and J visas covering students, postdoctoral researchers and visiting scholars, the new version offers no such carve outs. New entries from affected countries are blocked regardless of academic credentials or institutional sponsorship.Higher education associations and university immigration offices estimate that thousands of prospective students and scholars, potentially more than 10,000, could be affected by the policy. At institutions such as Harvard, administrators have warned that dozens of incoming researchers from banned countries may be unable to take up their positions.When draft versions of the ban appeared in media reports in March 2025, Pouyabahar attempted to accelerate her timeline. She rescheduled her PhD defence at short notice, preparing in just two weeks in the hope that an earlier completion date might protect her plans.Those efforts proved futile. The ban was announced only weeks after her visa interview, and she has said she never received a response. When she asked about the possibility of an exemption, she was told it was unlikely to help under the new policy framework.With the US option closed, Pouyabahar redirected her career to Canada, where she was already based and where immigration pathways for researchers remain more predictable. The move allowed her to continue her work, but it came at the cost of abandoning a carefully planned transition to one of the world‚Äôs most prestigious research environments.Her experience reflects a broader pattern among Iranian scholars affected by the ban. Many have quietly rerouted their careers to Canada or Europe, while others have delayed projects, lost funding opportunities or put academic plans on hold altogether.Economists and science policy researchers have consistently shown that high skilled immigrants play an outsized role in US innovation. Foreign born scientists account for a disproportionate share of patents, startups and breakthrough research, particularly in fields such as biotechnology and artificial intelligence.Critics argue that policies which exclude researchers like Pouyabahar undermine America‚Äôs scientific and economic competitiveness. Supporters of the ban frame it as a national security measure. What stands out, however, is how muted the political and public response has been compared with the airport protests and legal battles that followed the 2017 travel ban.Beyond the immediate career impact, Pouyabahar has described the psychological toll of the process, pointing to months of uncertainty over visa status, the risk of frozen grants and the constant fear of sudden policy changes.Reflecting on the outcome, she has said that in the current political climate she feels a sense of reluctant relief at not entering a system where immigration status can be overturned overnight. For her and many others, the experience has reshaped how they view the US as a destination for building a scientific career.

Her work focuses on developing tools that help scientists interpret complex biological data. The 2025 travel ban goes further than its 2017 predecessor. While the earlier policy eventually allowed exemptions for F and J visas covering students, postdoctoral researchers and visiting scholars, the new version offers no such carve outs.

Article Title: From Kash Patel to JD Vance: What Susie Wiles said about Team Trump
Article Text:
JD Vance: ‚ÄòA conspiracy theorist for a decade‚Äô

Trump, Vance & Karoline React To Susie Wiles‚Äô Vanity Fair Remarks

Donald Trump: ‚ÄòAn alcoholic‚Äôs personality‚Äô



Marco Rubio: The translator

Stephen Miller: The power of omission



Kash Patel and Dan Bongino: Belief versus truth

Pam Bondi: ‚ÄòCompletely whiffed‚Äô





Elon Musk: Hyperactive and uncontrollable





In a series of candid interviews with Vanity Fair, White House chief of staff Susie Wiles offered one of the clearest windows yet into the personalities driving Donald Trump‚Äôs second-term White House. Her remarks, measured but often blunt, sketch a governing circle defined by conviction, confrontation and competing ideas of power. At the centre sits Wiles herself, operating quietly, allowing strong figures to clash in public while she manages the internal balance behind closed doors.Wiles‚Äôs assessment of Vice President JD Vance is among her most striking. She is reported to have said that Vance ‚Äúhas been a conspiracy theorist for a decade‚Äù, framing his worldview as long-standing rather than newly adopted. The comment suggests scepticism about his intellectual grounding and the sources that shape his politics.She also implied that Vance‚Äôs journey from Trump critic to loyal ally was politically driven, tied to his Senate ambitions rather than a sudden ideological conversion. In Wiles‚Äôs telling, the evolution was calculated, reflecting ambition and opportunity more than persuasion.Wiles describes Trump as having ‚Äúan alcoholic‚Äôs personality‚Äù, despite the fact that he does not drink.By this, she means a temperament marked by compulsion, excess and an unshakeable belief that limits do not apply to him. Trump, she suggests, is fuelled by intensity and grievance, with a deep memory for perceived slights.She portrays him as someone who will pursue retribution if he sees an opening, whether against former officials or political adversaries. This instinct, she implies, is not chaotic but conditional, activated when Trump believes the moment is right.Marco Rubio emerges as a figure Wiles clearly trusts. Her description is spare but revealing. She says Rubio is someone who simply ‚Äúwon‚Äôt‚Äù abandon his principles, adding, ‚ÄúAnd so he had to get there.‚Äù The phrasing suggests persuasion rather than opportunism, patience rather than ambition.Rubio‚Äôs value lies in fluency. He understands Washington‚Äôs institutional language and can translate Trump‚Äôs instincts into terms that bureaucracies and allies still recognise. In an administration suspicious of process, that ability makes him indispensable.Stephen Miller is named as part of Wiles‚Äôs core team and then largely left unexplained. There is no extended quote dissecting his ideology or temperament, and the absence feels intentional. Miller does not require justification inside Trumpworld.His role is assumed, embedded and permanent. In this case, silence functions as description. He is a constant presence, neither questioned nor contextualised, reflecting how deeply his influence is woven into the administration‚Äôs machinery.Wiles treats Kash Patel and Dan Bongino with more nuance than outright praise or dismissal. She acknowledges that they ‚Äúreally appreciated what a big deal this is‚Äù because they ‚Äúlived in that world‚Äù, recognising their instinctive grasp of the emotional charge surrounding national security and institutional mistrust.At the same time, she draws a clear line between conviction and accuracy. Wiles notes that Patel pushed for disclosures for years based on assumptions that ‚Äúturn out not to be right‚Äù. In her telling, belief alone is not evidence, and certainty does not guarantee truth.Wiles is sharply critical of Attorney General Pam Bondi‚Äôs handling of the Jeffrey Epstein files. She is reported to have said Bondi ‚Äúcompletely whiffed‚Äù the rollout, particularly in how expectations were set among audiences eager for revelations.According to Wiles, Bondi initially delivered ‚Äúbinders full of nothingness‚Äù and later suggested that key documents or lists were ready for release when they were not. The episode, in Wiles‚Äôs view, damaged credibility and inflamed distrust within the administration‚Äôs own base.Her remarks about Elon Musk are among the most unsparing. Wiles is reported to have described Musk as an ‚Äúavowed ketamine user‚Äù and an eccentric whose actions often left her ‚Äúastounded‚Äù. She portrays him as hyperactive and difficult to restrain.Musk, she suggests, has a habit of breaking systems first and worrying about consequences later. While that approach may work in technology and business, Wiles implies it proved destabilising inside government, forcing others to manage fallout after decisions were already made.Across all these portraits, Wiles positions herself not as an enforcer or ideologue, but as an organiser. She allows aggressive loyalists and strong personalities to operate publicly while she remains largely off-camera, intervening selectively and strategically.The picture that emerges is of a White House driven by belief, grievance and ambition, with Wiles acting as the steady hand holding it together. Her comments offer a rare, unvarnished map of how power actually functions inside Trump‚Äôs inner circle.
Article Summary: White House chief of staff gives candid interview to Vanity Fair. She describes Donald Trump as having ‚Äòan alcoholic‚Äôs personality‚Äô Marco Rubio emerges as a figure Wiles clearly trusts. Pam Bondi is reported to have ‚Äòcompletely whiffed‚Äô the Jeffrey Epstein files.

Article Title: Pakistan: Former PM Imran Khan's sisters, supporters booked under anti-terrorism law; 14 arrested
Article Text:
Aleema Khan

‚ÄòMight Never See Him Again‚Äô: Imran Khan‚Äôs Sons Claim 'Psychological Torture' In Pak's Adiala Jail





Pakistan police on Wednesday registered a case under the Anti-Terrorism Act against the sisters of former prime minister Imran Khan and dozens of his supporters after a protest sit-in outside Adiala Jail in Rawalpindi.The protest on Tuesday was held after authorities refused to allow family members and lawyers to meet Khan, who is currently incarcerated. His sisters, along with leaders and workers of the Pakistan Tehreek-i-Insaf (PTI), staged the sit-in outside the jail to protest the restriction.Police said a first information report (FIR) was lodged at Police Station Saddar Beroni, Rawalpindi, naming Khan‚Äôs sisters Aleema Khan and Noreen Niazi, as well as several PTI leaders and supporters. Those named include Salman Akram Raja, Naeem Panjotha, Qasim Khan, Aliya Hamza and Raja Nasir Abbas.Authorities also invoked Section 120 of the Pakistan Penal Code for alleged criminal conspiracy against the state, along with charges of attacking police personnel and violating Section 144.Police said, as reported by PTI, at least 14 suspects were arrested at the scene late Tuesday night, and efforts are continuing to arrest others named in the FIR.Imran Khan has been in jail since August 2023 and faces multiple cases filed after his removal from office in April 2022.Officials have placed restrictions on meetings with Khan, saying such visits are being used for political purposes. The last meeting with him took place on December 2, when his sister Uzma Khan was allowed to see him.
Article Summary: Police register a case against the sisters of former prime minister Imran Khan and dozens of his supporters after a protest sit-in outside Adiala Jail in Rawalpindi. The protest was held after authorities refused to allow family members and lawyers to meet Khan, who is currently incarcerated.

Article Title: Still afloat, still fragile: How Pakistan economy is dodging a complete collapse ‚Äî explained
Article Text:
Quetta, Pakistan (AP file photo)

IMF‚Äôs New Conditions Expose Pakistan‚Äôs Deep Economic Faultlines Amid $7 Billion Rescue Package

(Source: IMF)

What is keeping Pakistan afloat

IMF support: Pakistan's key lifeline

(Source: IMF)

Tactical monetary management

Signs of financial market confidence

Tentative re-engagement with US

Deepening strategic and economic ties with China

The structural weaknesses holding Pakistan back

IMF's diagnosis of 'state capture' and 'elite privilege'

'Diagnosis is familiar, implementation is not'

Transparency concerns in federal structure

World Bank warning: stability without prosperity

India's decision to suspend IWT

(PTI file photo)

Operation Sindoor and security spillovers

Afghanistan's dams ‚Äî a second, converging shock

Survival without transformation





How is Pakistan‚Äôs economy still surviving? The question continues to arise as the country grapples with prolonged economic stress despite years of weak growth and low human development indicators.In recent years, Pakistan has dealt with sharp currency swings, runaways inflation between 2022 and 2024, persistent balance-of-payments pressures and mounting external debt burden. Yet the economy has managed to dodge a complete collapse, largely due to repeated bailouts from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and emergency financing from external partners.China has been key to this survival. Chinese loans and infrastructure investments have provided short-term relief but have also deepened Islamabad's financial dependence on Beijing. At the same time, Pakistan has sought to rebuild ties with the United States, long regarded as a key economic and diplomatic backstop.In this outreach, both army chief Asim Munir, now seen as the Pakistan's de facto power centre, and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif have taken apparent steps to engage Washington. The two leaders went ahead to nominate US President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize, citing his role in easing military tensions with India.However, New Delhi had turned down the claims of any foreign influence in peaceful agreement with Islamabad in May this year.And Uncle Sam responded with goodwill. Compared to several other countries, it was exempted from steep trade tariffs, with Washington announcing a lower levy of 19%. Trump has also spoken of possible cooperation in developing what he described as "massive oil reserves" in Pakistan.The power structure in Pakistan has also been a point of concern in its economic turmoil. The military's expanding role in governance has often overshadowed the civilian leadership, while former prime minister and a popular leader Imran Khan remains in prison, keeping political tensions high and weighing on investor confidence.Neighbouring countries have also added to Pakistan‚Äôs economic strain. India‚Äôs suspension of the Indus Waters Treaty has emerged as a major setback, while Afghanistan‚Äôs Taliban government has announced plans to build dams upstream, moves that could further affect water availability and pose another risk to Pakistan‚Äôs economy and GDP growth.For now, Pakistan‚Äôs economy continues to function through foreign assistance, administrative controls and short-term stabilisation measures. Without sustained political stability, meaningful reforms and an effective check on corruption, its economic survival remains fragile.One of the most important stabilisers of Pakistan's economy has been the continued support from the International Monetary Fund and other multilateral lenders.The Governance and Corruption Diagnostic Assessment (GCDA) finalised in November 2025, was released ahead of the Fund's executive board's expected approval of a $1.2 billion disbursement, part of the ongoing 37-month, $7 billion programme started under the prime ministership of Shehbaz Sharif.With the latest approval, Pakistan has received around $3.3 billion from the IMF since last year. Under the bailout programme, Islamabad will continue to receive loan instalments over a 37-month period, contingent on meeting the agreed reform conditions.Pakistan narrowly avoided default in 2023 only after the IMF extended an earlier nine-month emergency deal, which was followed by the current longer programme. Since 1958, Pakistan has turned to the IMF 25 times, making it one of the IMF's most frequent borrowers.In 2025, IMF disbursements helped rebuild foreign exchange buffers, reassure markets and finance imports and debt servicing, according to Reuters.Pakistan's central bank has used monetary policy as a tactical tool to stabilise inflation while cautiously supporting growth.On December 15, the State Bank of Pakistan cut its key interest rate by 50 basis points to 10.5%, breaking a four-meeting hold. The SBP said the move was aimed at supporting sustainable economic growth while keeping inflation within target.According to Reuters, all 12 analysts in a Reuters poll had expected the central bank to hold the policy rate at 11%, particularly after the IMF warned against premature easing under Pakistan's $7 billion loan programme.The rate cut highlighted Pakistan's effort to revive domestic economic activity without destabilising the IMF-backed stabilisation framework.Despite underlying weaknesses, Pakistan has seen improving sentiment in financial markets.Credit ratings agencies S&P Global, Fitch and Moody‚Äôs upgraded Pakistan‚Äôs credit ratings in 2025, citing stronger finances and revenue gains. Investor appetite for Pakistan‚Äôs dollar bonds and equities has strengthened, with bonds delivering nearly 22% returns this year and the benchmark stock index gaining 44%, among the best performers in Asia.Bloomberg Economics estimates growth quickened to 3.4% year-on-year in the second quarter, with official data expected shortly.However, with the backdrop of political chaos, most notably the continued imprisonment of the country's most popular political figure, Imran Khan, investors have little confidence to make long-term plans in Pakistan.Pakistan has also moved to rebuild economic ties with the United States.According to Bloomberg, Islamabad is planning an investor conference in Washington to draw American investment in energy, mining and technology. Finance minister Muhammad Aurangzeb said the sectors where Pakistan seeks US investment are clearly identified.Economic links have improved following a new US-Pakistan trade deal setting a 19% tariff, lower than regional peers and well below the 50% tariff imposed on India.Meanwhile, Trump also promised to help Pakistan develop what he described as "massive oil reserves" on Pakistani soil. The remarks followed sustained praise and outreach from Pakistan‚Äôs de facto power centre, army chief Asim Munir, and were later echoed by Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, who went on to nominate Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize on several occasions.‚ÄúThe first thing was to get the trade equation out of the way, which it is now,‚Äù Aurangzeb told Bloomberg."Every single industry in Pakistan has to have an export component, because it‚Äôs the only way we're going to get out of this boom-and-bust cycle," Aurangzeb added.Beyond Western partners, Pakistan continues to rely heavily on China.According to the Middle East Institute, Pakistan‚Äôs strategic reliance on Beijing has deepened, particularly through the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). In January, Dawn reported that Pakistan and China reaffirmed their commitment to high-quality development of CPEC 2.0, focusing on industrialisation, special economic zones, clean energy, agriculture and livelihood projects.Chinese support has provided Pakistan with infrastructure investment, energy projects and diplomatic backing at moments of economic stress.While IMF financing has stabilised Pakistan, the IMF's own assessment paints a deeply troubling picture of governance in the Islamic Republic.The IMF's Governance and Corruption Diagnostic Assessment concluded that corruption in Pakistan is driven by "state capture", where public policy is manipulated to benefit a narrow circle of political and business elites.The 186-page report described dysfunctional institutions unable to enforce the rule of law or protect public resources. Corruption, the IMF said, is persistent and corrosive, distorting markets, eroding public trust and undermining fiscal stability.The report warns that without dismantling entrenched structures of elite privilege, Pakistan‚Äôs economic stagnation will persist.According to the IMF, the most economically damaging corruption involves privileged entities that exert influence over key economic sectors, including those owned by or affiliated with the state.Stefan Dercon, a professor of economic policy at the University of Oxford who has advised Pakistan on reforms, told Al Jazeera that lack of accountability continues to erode economic potential."Failure of implementation [of laws and principles of accountability] gives vested interests too often free rein and addressing this must be at the core of efforts for economic reform," Dercon said.Ali Hasanain, associate professor of economics at the Lahore University of Management Sciences, said the IMF‚Äôs findings mirror long-standing domestic research."The IMF diagnostic repeats what many domestic studies, including those by the World Bank and Pakistan‚Äôs own institutions, have already emphasised: Powerful interests shape rules to maintain their advantage," Hasanain told Al Jazeera.A 2021 UNDP report found that economic privileges granted to Pakistan‚Äôs elite, including politicians and the powerful military, amount to roughly 6 percent of GDP.The IMF report also flags governance risks linked to the Special Investment Facilitation Council (SIFC), created in June 2023 to promote investment and comprising both civilian and military leaders.The GCDA raises concerns over broad legal immunity granted to SIFC officials and the council‚Äôs authority to exempt projects from regulatory requirements.‚ÄúThe recently established Special Investment Facilitation Council, which has been vested with substantial authority to facilitate foreign investments, operates with untested transparency and accountability provisions,‚Äù the IMF report said.The Fund urged greater transparency, including annual public reporting on investments facilitated and concessions granted.The World Bank has warned that macroeconomic stabilisation has not translated into meaningful improvements in living standards."Business as usual is not good for the economy," said Mukhtar Ul Hasan, World Bank economist and lead author of a report on Pakistan."Pakistan's growth potential has been declining for decades" due to weak competitiveness, limited reforms and recurring crises, he added.The World Bank projects growth of 3% this year and 3.4% next year, far below what is needed to absorb 1.6 million new labour market entrants annually.The Bank‚Äôs poverty and resilience report shows poverty rising again to over 27% by 2023‚Äì24, with nearly half the population living below the lower-middle-income poverty line. Rural areas, especially Balochistan and interior Sindh, face far greater deprivation.Geopolitics has added new economic risks.After a Pakistan-sponsored terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir‚Äôs Pahalgam that killed 26 civilians, India answered strongly to its misadventure by putting the Indus Waters Treaty in abeyance. Islamabad responded by warning that any attempt to stop or divert water flows would be treated as an "act of war."Around 80% of Pakistani farms depend on the Indus system, as do nearly all hydropower projects. India had also identified hydropower projects in Jammu and Kashmir that could expand capacity to 12,000 MW from the current 3,360 MW, according to Reuters.In May 2025 India‚Äôs crossborder counterterror action under Operation Sindoor, marked a sharp escalation in India-Pakistan security dynamics. Military operations and reciprocal measures elevate defence spending, crowd out development spending, spook investors, and raise insurance and logistics costs for trade.Pakistan suffered a major setback after Indian strikes severely damaged nine of its key airbases, including Nur Khan and Rahim Yar Khan, dealing a significant blow to its military infrastructure.Pakistan‚Äôs economic capacity has been heavily drained by sustained military expenditure driven by its adversarial policies toward India, a burden that has come at the cost of investment in social sectors and has pushed the country down across multiple human development indicators.Reports indicate Afghanistan's new dam projects on rivers that feed Pakistan (Kunar/Kabul tributaries) will further diminish cross-border flows into Pakistan‚Äôs north-west. Combined with India‚Äôs measures, this convergence would be a "double blast" to Pakistani water security ‚Äî concentrated in already drought-prone provinces that supply major agricultural output.Reduced river flows affect irrigation, livelihoods and hydroelectricity; they also fuel internal migration pressures and raise the social cost of adjustment. Regional cooperation mechanisms for water management have weakened, making unilateral upstream development a direct economic shock for downstream Pakistan.Pakistan‚Äôs economy is surviving due to IMF support, tactical policy moves, selective foreign investment and geopolitical manoeuvring, including heavy dependence on China and US.But without deep structural reform, dismantling elite privilege and restoring institutional accountability, survival may continue without delivering broad-based prosperity, leaving the country trapped in the same cycle of crisis and rescue that has defined its economic history.
Article Summary: Pakistan narrowly avoided default in 2023 only after the IMF extended an earlier nine-month emergency deal. Since 1958, Pakistan has turned to the IMF 25 times, making it one of the IMF's most borrowers. Without sustained political stability, meaningful reforms and an effective check on corruption, Pakistan's economic survival remains fragile.

Article Title: Trump, troops and trouble at home: Why Asim Munir's next move could shake Pakistan
Article Text:
Pakistan army chief Asim Munir (AP file photo)

Trump Puts Asim Munir On Gaza Test: Can Pak Army Chief Appease U.S & Avoid Backlash At Home?

'Pressure to deliver'

Munir's unprecedented power

Risks at home





Pakistan's de facto state head and most powerful army chief in decades is facing the toughest test of his expanding stronghold in Islamabad power centre as the United States presses Islamabad to send troops to a Gaza stabilisation force, a move analysts told Reuters could spark strong domestic backlash. It could also "annoy the US president" if Munir shows disinterest in contributing to the peace plan.Military chief Munir, who holds enormous influenceover Pakistan's political and economic decisions, is expected to travel to Washington in the coming weeks to meet US President Donald Trump . It would be their third meeting in six months and is likely to focus on Pakistan's possible role in Gaza, according to two sources familiar with the matter, one of whom is closely involved in Munir‚Äôs economic outreach to the US.Trump's proposed 20-point plan for Gaza calls for troops from Muslim-majority countries to oversee a transition period focused on reconstruction and economic recovery in the Palestinian territory. Gaza has been devastated by more than two years of Israeli military bombardment.Many countries are cautious about joining such a force because it could involve disarming Hamas, Gaza's Islamist militant group. Analysts say this risks pulling foreign troops deeper into the conflict and could inflame pro-Palestinian and anti-Israeli public opinion at home.Munir, however, has developed close ties with Trump as part of an effort to repair years of strained relations between Washington and Islamabad. In June, Trump hosted Munir for a private lunch at the White House ‚Äî the first time a US president met Pakistan‚Äôs army chief alone, without any civilian leaders present."Not contributing (to the Gaza stabilisation force) could annoy Trump, which is no small matter for a Pakistani state that appears quite keen to remain in his good graces - in great part to secure U.S. investment and security aid," said Michael Kugelman, Senior Fellow, South Asia at the Washington-based Atlantic Council.Pakistan is the world's only Muslim-majority country with nuclear weapons and has a powerful, experienced military. It has fought three wars with rival India, a brief conflict earlier this year, and has long battled insurgencies in its remote regions. It is also currently fighting Islamist militants that it says operate from neighbouring Afghanistan.Because of this military capability, expectations are higher for Pakistan to contribute, said defence analyst and author Ayesha Siddiqa.Pakistan‚Äôs military strength means "there is a greater pressure on Munir to deliver his capacity," she said.Pakistan‚Äôs military, foreign office and information ministry did not respond to Reuters‚Äô questions. The White House also did not reply to a request for comment.Foreign Minister Ishaq Dar said last month that Pakistan could consider contributing troops for peacekeeping, but made clear that disarming Hamas was not Islamabad‚Äôs responsibility.Earlier this month, Munir was appointed chief of the defence forces, placing the army, air force and navy under his command. He also received a job extension until 2030.Under constitutional amendments passed by Pakistan‚Äôs civilian government last month, Munir will retain his field marshal rank for life and enjoy lifetime immunity from criminal prosecution."Few people in Pakistan enjoy the luxury of being able to take risks more than Munir. He has unbridled power, now constitutionally protected," Kugelman said.In recent weeks, Munir has met leaders from Indonesia, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Jordan, Egypt and Qatar, according to military statements. Siddiqa said these meetings appear aimed at consulting Muslim countries on the proposed Gaza force.At home, however, the biggest risk is political unrest. Any deployment of Pakistani troops to Gaza under a US-backed plan could revive protests by Islamist parties that strongly oppose the US and Israel.These groups have the ability to bring thousands of supporters onto the streets.In October, authorities banned a powerful and violent Islamist party known for pushing Pakistan‚Äôs strict blasphemy laws. Officials said its leaders were arrested, more than 1,500 supporters detained, and its assets and bank accounts seized. Despite the ban, analysts say the group‚Äôs ideology still has influence.Supporters of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan, whose party won the most seats in the 2024 elections, are also deeply hostile to Munir and could mobilise against him.Abdul Basit, Senior Associate Fellow at Singapore‚Äôs S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies, warned that any escalation after deployment could quickly spiral."People will say 'Asim Munir is doing Israel's bidding' - it will be foolhardy of anyone not to see it coming."
Article Summary: Pakistan's de facto state head and most powerful army chief in decades is facing the toughest test of his expanding stronghold in Islamabad power centre. Asim Munir is expected to travel to Washington in the coming weeks to meet US President Donald Trump. It would be their third meeting in six months.

Article Title: Lahore-Multan bus-trailer collision leaves hostess dead, injures 14
Article Text:
Lahore-Multan bus-trailer collision leaves hostess dead, injures 14





KHANEWAL (PAKISTAN): A bus hostess was killed, and at least 14 passengers were injured on Saturday after a passenger bus collided with a trailer near the Makhdoom Pur Interchange on the M-4 Motorway, triggering a large-scale rescue operation, ARY News reported.According to Rescue 1122 officials, the emergency control room received an alert about a serious crash involving a bus travelling from Lahore to Multan.Rescue teams were immediately dispatched to the scene, where they found several passengers trapped inside the damaged vehicle, according to ARY News.Rescue personnel worked swiftly to evacuate everyone trapped inside the bus. Nine injured passengers were given first aid at the accident site, while five others were found to be in critical condition. The bus hostess died on the spot due to the impact of the collision.Rescue 1122 shifted the dead body and all injured passengers to the Tehsil Headquarters (THQ) Hospital, Kabirwala.A spokesperson for the Motorway Police said preliminary findings indicate the accident was caused by the bus driver's negligence and drowsiness. Authorities have launched a detailed investigation to determine the exact circumstances leading to the crash.In a separate incident earlier this week, a four-year-old child was killed after being run over by a water tanker in the Farid Colony area of Orangi Town. The incident, reported by ARY News, was the third heavy traffic accident recorded in the area on Wednesday.Police said the child, identified as Sufiyan, died on the spot. The accident occurred within the jurisdiction of Momin Abad Police Station in the Faqeer Colony area.The tanker driver fled the scene following the incident, while police took the vehicle into custody and launched a search to trace the driver.Both incidents have once again highlighted concerns over road safety and the growing number of fatal accidents involving heavy vehicles.
Article Summary: Bus travelling from Lahore to Multan collided with trailer on M-4 Motorway. Bus hostess died on the spot due to the impact of the collision. Four-year-old child killed after being run over by water tanker in Orangi Town.

Article Title: Gatecrash or misrepresentation? Did Pakistan PM Shehbaz Sharif interrupt Putin's closed-door meeting? Fact check
Article Text:
Putin Keeps Sharif Waiting In Ashgabat, Desperate Pakistan PM Gate-Crashes Meeting With Erdogan

Counteroffensives against the Triad

The challenges Pakistan faces today are often described in binary terms ‚Äî a threat here, a conflict there ‚Äî but the reality is far more chaotic and intricate, much like the scientific conundrum known as the "three-body problem". This problem, rooted in physics and celestial mechanics, deals with predicting the motions of three gravitational bodies interacting with each other. The paradox is that while two bodies' orbits can be predicted with relative simplicity, introducing a third body creates a system so unstable and non-linear that exact forecasts become practically impossible. Pakistan's existential security dilemmas resemble this dynamic complexity: three powerful, interrelated forces that simultaneously influence and destabilize the country‚Äôs internal and external equilibrium.These three forces are the Taliban , the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan ( TTP ), and the Baloch insurgency.Individually, each represents a serious security threat. Collectively, their interactions generate overlapping, tangled challenges that confound policy, military strategy, and diplomatic efforts.Recent escalations are a stark reminder of this peril. In October 2025, Pakistan launched airstrikes in Kabul and other Afghan sites targeting TTP leader Noor Wali Mehsud, prompting Taliban retaliation on Pakistani border posts and further Pakistani precision strikes killing dozens of militants.Meanwhile, Baloch attacks surged 53% in 2024 to 938 incidents with over 1,002 fatalities, spilling into 2025 with high-profile hits on CPEC projects.Over 300 attacks rocked Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in 2025 alone, mostly TTP-led.For the first time since 2015, the number of terror attacks in Pakistan crossed the 900-mark.Grasping their interplay is crucial to understanding why Pakistan‚Äôs security apparatus struggles to restore stability ‚Äî and why conventional approaches have so far failed.The Taliban, an Islamist militant group born in Afghanistan in the mid-1990s, rose to international prominence with its capture of Kabul in 1996.Following the US invasion after 9/11, the group was ousted but persisted with insurgency tactics. The Taliban's return to power in Afghanistan in 2021 reshaped regional dynamics and profoundly impacted Pakistan.For Pakistan, the Taliban's ascendance is something of a double-edged sword. On one hand, Islamabad sees the group as a strategic asset to exert influence in Kabul and counter Indian presence in Afghanistan. On the other hand, the Taliban's ideological affinity with Pakistan's own Pashtun tribal regions and cross-border networks complicates Islamabad's control over militancy within its own borders.The Taliban's ideology and governance style also inspire elements within Pakistan, especially in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and the tribal belt. This ideological inspiration runs parallel to fears that the group's Afghan governance failures or hardline policies could spill over, destabilising Pakistan‚Äôs own tribal regions.The Afghan Taliban's 2021 takeover initially promised Pakistan leverage against India, but it backfired spectacularly. Kabul's refusal to dismantle TTP sanctuaries hosting 6,000-6,500 fighters armed with leftover NATO weapons has fueled Islamabad's woes. Tensions peaked in December 2025 with heavy cross-border fire exchanges killing five Afghans, amid soured ties since 2021.Experts like Tahir Khan note the Taliban's inaction strains relations, pushing Pakistan to airstrikes that risk radicalising more TTP factions toward rivals like ISKP. Failed Istanbul peace talks in October 2025 saw Pakistan threaten to "obliterate" the Taliban regime after unmet demands on TTP expulsion. Sirajuddin Haqqani dismissed TTP as Pakistan's "internal matter," vowing forceful responses to violations.This dynamic grants TTP "strategic depth" unparalleled in its history, enabling mergers and centralisation under Mehsud. As analyst Hazrat Ali warns, Pakistani pressure on Kabul could splinter TTP, worsening regional chaos.Pakistan‚Äôs newly appointed armed forces chief Gen. Asim Munir recently called on Afghanistan‚Äôs Taliban government to choose between maintaining ties with Islamabad or supporting the Pakistani Taliban.Munir said that a ‚Äúclear message‚Äù had been delivered to the Taliban government in Kabul: it must decide between Pakistan and ‚ÄúFitna al-Khawarij,‚Äù a term authorities use for the outlawed Pakistani Taliban, known a s Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan.While the Afghan Taliban exerts influence across the border, the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan represents a homegrown, highly violent insurgency directly challenging the Pakistani state‚Äôs writ. Originating as an umbrella militant organisation around 2007, the TTP embodies a coalition of various Islamist militants and tribal groups united against Islamabad's military operations.The TTP has been responsible for some of the deadliest terrorist attacks in Pakistan over the past decade, targeting military installations, government buildings, schools, and civilian populations. Despite several attempted peace negotiations, the TTP's fractured yet resilient network has shown a capacity to regroup, regrouping largely within the tribal regions of northwestern Pakistan and even spilling across the Afghan border during periods of instability.The group opposes Pakistan‚Äôs state institutions vehemently and views the military, intelligence agencies, and secular political frameworks as existential enemies. Unlike the Afghan Taliban, which now nominally controls Kabul, the TTP pursues a more violent, confrontational agenda rooted in the Pakistani context.The TTP roared back post-Taliban victory. In 2024, it drove over half of 900+ attacks in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, killing 560+, with 67% targeting security forces. By 2025, its operations hit 600+ confrontations, surpassing all of 2024.A stark October 8, 2025, ambush in Kurram killed 11 Pakistani soldiers, including two officers, via roadside bombs and heavy weapons‚Äîexposing border vulnerabilities.TTP now eyes tribal belt control, mirroring Afghan Taliban's path, per CTC West Point analysis. Mehsud's unification of splinters has boosted recruitment, with propaganda invoking Baloch grievances to broaden appeal.Security data shows 96% of attacks in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, blending armed assaults and IEDs, as TTP demands military divestment from businesses. This resurgence, analysts say, stems from Afghan havens, turning Pakistan's past militant proxies into monsters.Simultaneously, Pakistan faces an insurgency in Balochistan‚Äîa sprawling, resource-rich, but underdeveloped southwestern province. The Baloch nationalist movement goes back decades, demanding greater autonomy, resource control, and sometimes outright independence. The insurgency has fluctuated in intensity but remains a persistent thorn in Islamabad‚Äôs side.Baloch militants have targeted Pakistani security forces, infrastructure projects, and economic installations such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)‚Äîa flagship regional development initiative. The province's rugged terrain and Baloch tribal dynamics create a challenging environment for Pakistani counterinsurgency efforts.Unlike the religious militancy of the Taliban and TTP, the Baloch insurgency is rooted in ethnic nationalism and grievances over political marginalization, economic neglect, and human rights abuses. This ideological and geographical distinctiveness makes it harder for the Pakistani state to craft a unified internal security strategy.Attacks ballooned to 327 sites across 25 districts in 2024, with 80% fatality spike to 1,002+. The March 11, 2025, Jaffar Express hijacking by BLA-Jeeyand killed 26 hostages and kidnapped 400+, showcasing tactical evolution from hit-and-runs to coordinated ops.CPEC remains prime target: Operation Dara-e-Bolan in January 2024 and March 2025 barrages hit Chinese workers, amid Israel-Iran and India-Pakistan tensions stoking fears of wider nexuses. BLA's sophistication targets BRI, militarizing the region further.Unlike TTP's jihadism, Baloch fights for autonomy, but heavy state crackdowns alienate locals, per CTC analysis. Injuries rose to 689, property losses to 546, signaling expanded reach despite counter-ops killing 76 insurgents.Here lies Pakistan‚Äôs three-body problem: the Taliban, TTP, and Baloch insurgency don‚Äôt operate in isolation.Their influences collide, interact, and ripple across Pakistan‚Äôs geopolitical landscape in unpredictable ways.Traditional counterinsurgency and counterterrorism strategies rely on clear, identifiable enemies that can be neutralised through military might, intelligence operations, or negotiated settlements. The three-body dynamic, however, forces Pakistan to wrestle with fluid, overlapping, and at times contradictory challenges.In essence, each "body" in this problem pulls Pakistan‚Äôs security landscape in different directions, making any single policy or operation insufficient.Addressing this three-body problem requires Pakistan to adopt a holistic, integrated strategy that acknowledges the distinct yet intertwined nature of these challenges.Pakistan's military has intensified operations since mid-2025 to counter the Taliban-TTP-Baloch nexus, focusing on intelligence-based strikes (IBOs), cross-border actions, and sustained ground campaigns amid over 1,000 attacks nationwide. These efforts emphasize decapitation of TTP leadership, border denial, and Baloch insurgency suppression, though resource strains from multi-front threats limit gains.The army launched precision airstrikes into Afghanistan targeting TTP hideouts. On October 9, 2025, raids hit Kabul, Khost, Jalalabad, and Paktika, aiming at TTP chief Noor Wali Mehsud's headquarters, killing dozens of militants despite his survival claim. Retaliatory Taliban attacks on border posts prompted further Pakistani strikes on October 11-12, neutralizing Taliban brigades and TTP operatives.Recent IBOs in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa yielded kills: December 5-6 saw nine TTP fighters eliminated in Tank and Lakki Marwat districts. September 13 clashes in South Waziristan and Lower Dir killed 35 militants but cost 19 soldiers, highlighting ambush risks. December 6-7 Chaman border strikes destroyed three Taliban bases, killing 23 fighters after ceasefire violations.Operation Azm-e-Istehkam, ramped up in summer 2025, reports near-daily TTP neutralizations in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, addressing a terrorism surge to highest levels since 2015.In Balochistan, May 2025 operations deployed over 40 vehicles in Surab, Zehri, and Khuzdar, declaring areas "sensitive" to hunt Baloch Liberation Army (BLA) amid 70+ attacks under Operation Herof. August 30 actions post-BLA civilian strikes killed five insurgents and captured two in Kech, part of Azm-e-Istehkam's escalation.Security forces targeted BLA convoys, camps, and intelligence squads, seizing arms despite BLA claims of 25 blockades and 15 camp captures in 2024-2025. These ops focus on CPEC protection, countering 938 incidents with 1,002 fatalities in 2024 extending into 2025.The ongoing volatility reveals that no single strategy will yield a definitive victory; instead, Pakistan must adopt nuanced, integrated policies that combine hard military pressure with political dialogue, regional diplomacy, and socioeconomic inclusion.The future of Pakistan‚Äôs sovereignty and regional peace depends on how skillfully it navigates this chaotic three-body problem, turning a disordered struggle into a managed equilibrium before the forces pull the nation into further unrest and fragmentation.

Article Title: Pakistan ex-ISI chief jailed: Faiz Hameed convicted after court martial; handed 14 years in prison

A Pakistani military court has sentenced former inter-services intelligence (ISI) director general Lt Gen (retd) Faiz Hameed to 14 years in prison after a 15-month-long court-martial on multiple charges, including political interference and violations of the official secrets act.The Field General Court Martial, held under the Pakistan army act, found Hameed guilty on four counts - engaging in political activities, misuse of authority and state resources, violation of the official secrets act, and causing wrongful loss to individuals. Khan - who was ousted in 2022 through a no-confidence vote and has since criticized the military and political leadership for his removal - is serving multiple jail terms on graft and other charges. The military, Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif‚Äôs government and the US have all denied Khan‚Äôs claim that they engineered his exit.
Article Summary: Lt Gen (retd) Faiz Hameed sentenced to 14 years in prison. Convicted on multiple charges, including political interference and violations of the official secrets act. Once considered a close confidant of jailed former prime minister Imran Khan.
